author: Financial News
title: Saxo adds heavyweight broking names to UK board
text:
James Rundle 13 October 2015 Saxo Capital Markets, the UK arm of Saxo Bank, has recruited two veterans of the trading and broking sector, Richard Balarkas and David Gelber, to its board, as part of its efforts to tackle increasing complexities in the trading sector. Richard Balarkas 
The addition as non-executive directors of electronic trading veteran Balarkas, who was chief executive of agency broker Instinet Europe from 2008 to 2012, and Gelber, a former operating chief at interdealer broker Icap and in HSBC's global markets division, follows the recruitment in September 2014 of Anthony Belchambers, the founder of FIA Europe, formerly the Futures & Options Association, to the board, which he now chairs. 
Balarkas, who has also held senior electronic trading posts at Credit Suisse, BZW and the London Stock Exchange, is a consultant through his Quendon Consulting business, and in 2012 won Financial News’s Excellence in Trading and Technology Award for Personal Contribution of the Decade . 
Gelber, meanwhile, has worked for Citibank and JP Morgan, and is chairman of Walker Crisps Group, and has held directorships for eSecLending and GlobeOp Financial Services. 
Their arrivals, which were announced in a statement from Saxo on October 13, are the latest changes to the board, while Belchambers takes over the chairman post previously held by Nick Beecroft, a former global head of foreign exchange at Standard Chartered, who stepped down from his Saxo post on July 9. 
Matteo Cassina, the chief executive of Saxo Capital Markets UK, said in a statement that the appointments reflect the "significant transformation of Saxo Bank’s business in the UK". 
He added: "Our ambition is to further build out our multi-asset trading capabilities with London as a major hub for our institutional offering and facilitate partnerships and collaborations that make trading and investment opportunities accessible and efficient." 
Other arrivals at Saxo over the past year include former Rabobank executive Peter Plester as head of foreign exchange prime of prime brokerage, former Deutsche Bank executive Gerard Lelliott as head of prime of prime services, and another ex-Deutsche Bank executive, Alessandro Bressan, who leads Saxo's global equities business.
